raw.author: Franz Kafka
contexts: Yet the only exact description of this predicament is to be found, as far as I know, in one of those parables of Franz Kafka which, unique perhaps in this respect in literature, are real , thrown alongside and around the incident like rays of light which, however, do not illuminate its outward appearance but possess the power of X rays to lay bare its inner structure that, in our case, consists of the hidden processes of the mind.

The situation, as it presents itself today, oddly resembles an elaborate verification of a remark by Franz Kafka, written at the very beginning of this development: Man, he said, “found the Archimedean point, but he used it against himself; it seems that he was permitted to find it only under this condition.”
Arendt’s interpretation of Kafka’s story called simply “HE,”
That is now in the Library of Congress, Arendt analyzes concepts of time from Plato to Augustine to Hegel to Kafka
commentaries: The author cites Kafka's parables as providing the only exact description of the modern predicament of thought and reality, praising their unique ability to reveal the inner structure of the mind.
The author cites a remark by Kafka to illustrate the paradoxical and self-destructive potential of humanity's search for an absolute, Archimedean point of leverage.
The author references Kafka as the source of a parable about time and the thinker's position, which Arendt interprets and later 'corrects'.
The author references Kafka as a thinker whose concept of time is analyzed by Arendt in an unpublished document.

raw.author: Cicero
contexts: just as it was the reason for Cicero’s contention that only through building and preserving political communities could human virtue attain to the ways of the gods.25

and Cicero could say, "In no other realm does human excellence approach so closely the paths of the gods (numen) as it does in the founding of new and in the preservation of already founded communities."
Cicero, for instance, appeals explicitly to Scipio to become dictator rei publicae constituendae, to seize the dictatorship in order to restore the republic.60

It seems it was Cicero who first used the word for matters of spirit and mind. He speaks of excolere animum, of cultivating the mind, and of cultura animi in the same sense in which we speak even today of a cultured mind
Cicero. De legibus I, 5; De oratore II, 55.
The derivation of religio from religare occurs in Cicero.
It is curious to see how seldom Cicero’s name occurs in Machiavelli’s writings and how carefully he avoided him in his interpretations of Roman history.

Cicero, in his Tusculan Disputations, I, 13, says explicitly that the mind is like a field which cannot be productive without proper cultivation—and then declares: Cultura autem animi philosophia est.
Cicero, op. cit., V, 9.

Plato’s violent polemics against Homer and the Homeric religion
Homer’s description of Hades in the eleventh book of the Odyssey.
the poet Homer
Homeric impartiality rested upon the assumption that great things are self-evident, shine by themselves; that the poet (or later the historiographer) has only to preserve their glory
What Homer had done was to immortalize human deeds,29
as though Homerically speaking the spirit of Hector had survived the fall of Troy and been resurrected on Italian soil

I think it can be traced to the moment when Homer chose to sing the deeds of the Trojans no less than those of the Achaeans, and to praise the glory of Hector, the foe and the defeated man, no less than the glory of Achilles, the hero of his kinfolk.

raw.author: Immanuel Kant
contexts: Immanuel Kant, whom Marx called the philosopher of the French (or bourgeois) Revolution, saw the revolutionaries’ will to freedom, despite its contradictions, well-nigh irresistible.

the only great thinker who dared to go against the grain of the question was Immanuel Kant, who boldly explained that the “proverbial saying . . . means in simple language: ‘Justice shall prevail, even though all the rascals in the world should perish as a result.’”

First they became what they had been for Plato only in their relationship to the political realm, standards and measurements, or the regulating, limiting forces of man’s own reasoning mind, as they appear in Kant.
finally inspired Kant’s gigantic effort to re-examine the human faculties

In Kant’s own words: “It will always remain bewildering . . . that the earlier generations seem to carry on their burdensome business only for the sake of the later . . . and that only the last should have the good fortune to dwell in the [completed] building.”36

only in Kant’s reply to Plato: “It is not to be expected that kings philosophize or that philosophers become kings, nor is it to be desired, because the possession of power corrupts the free judgment of reason inevitably”

The greatest clarification in these obscure matters we owe to Kant and to his insight that freedom is no more ascertainable to the inner sense and within the field of inner experience than it is to the senses with which we know and understand the world.
Kant saved freedom from this twofold assault upon it by distinguishing between a “pure” or theoretical reason and a “practical reason” whose center is free will
This attitude of disinterested joy (to use the Kantian term, uninteressiertes Wohlgefallen)
Kant’s categorical imperative, the only competitor in the field, could be stripped of its Judaeo-Christian ingredients...
as Kant said, 'general precepts learned at the feet either of priests or philosophers, or even drawn from one's own resources, are never so efficacious as an example of virtue or holiness.'
The reason, as Kant explains, is that we always need 'intuitions ... to verify the reality of our concepts.'
commentaries: The author references Kant as the philosopher of the French Revolution, noting his view on the revolutionaries' will to freedom.
The author references Kant's interpretation of a Latin adage about justice, highlighting his stance on the primacy of justice over worldly survival.
The author cites Kant as a philosopher who reinterpreted Platonic ideas as regulatory principles of human reason.
The author notes that the same fundamental suspicion of the senses inspired Kant's critical re-examination of human faculties.
The author quotes Kant to illustrate his concept of history and the perplexities it introduced into political philosophy.
The author quotes Kant's direct reply to Plato's political proposal, noting it identifies a danger to philosophy.
The author credits Kant with providing the greatest clarification on the problem of freedom, particularly his insight about its unascertainability.
The author references Kant's philosophical distinction between theoretical and practical reason as a solution to the problem of freedom.
The author references Kant as the source of the philosophical term 'uninteressiertes Wohlgefallen' (disinterested pleasure) to describe the proper aesthetic attitude.
The author compares Kant's categorical imperative to the Socratic ethical proposition, suggesting its underlying principle is the axiom of non-contradiction.
The author cites Kant to support the argument that practical concepts require intuitive examples from history or poetry for verification.
The author references Kant's epistemological point about the necessity of intuitions (schemata or examples) to verify concepts, applying it to moral philosophy.

raw.author: Tocqueville
contexts: When Tocqueville returned from the New World, which he so superbly knew how to describe and to analyze that his work has remained a classic and survived more than a century of radical change, he was well aware of the fact that what Char called the “completion” of act and event had still eluded him; and Char’s “Our inheritance was left to us by no testament” sounds like a variation of Tocqueville’s “Since the past has ceased to throw its light upon the future, the mind of man wanders in obscurity.”

For what else but despair could have inspired Tocqueville’s assertion that “since the past has ceased to throw its light upon the future the mind of man wanders in obscurity”? This is actually the conclusion of the great work in which he had “delineated the society of the modern world” and in the introduction to which he had proclaimed that “a new science of politics is needed for a new world.”33
the concomitant trust in an “indefinite perfectibility”—which Tocqueville noted as the credo of the common “uninstructed man”
commentaries: The author references Tocqueville's work as a classic analysis of the New World, noting his awareness of the lack of 'completion' in historical understanding, and draws a parallel between Tocqueville's statement and Char's aphorism about inheritance without testament.

The author quotes and analyzes Tocqueville, citing his despair over the disconnection between past and future and his call for a new political science, to illustrate the decline of pure political theory in the 19th century.
The author references Tocqueville's observation about the American belief in indefinite perfectibility, using it to explain a cultural attitude that predates similar developments in the West.

raw.title: Between Past and Future
raw.author: Hannah Arendt
contexts: The last essay in Between Past and Future, “The Conquest of Space and the Stature of Man,” illuminates the consequences of earth-alienation, a sort of self-willed exile from the earth.
commentaries: The author describes the content and theme of an essay within the book.

goodreads_match.title: Between Past and Future
goodreads_match.description: Arendt's penetrating observations of the modern world, based on a profound knowledge of the past, constitute a major contribution to political philosophy. In this book she describes the perplexing crises which modern society faces as a result of the loss of meaning of the traditional key words of politics: justice, reason, responsibility, virtue, and glory. Through a series of eight exercises, she shows how we can redistill once more the vital essence of these concepts.

goodreads_match.title: Metaphysics
goodreads_match.description: Metaphysics (Greek: ta meta ta phusika) is one of the principal works of Aristotle & the first major work of the branch of philosophy with the same name. The principal subject is "being qua being", or being understood as being. It examines what can be asserted about anything that exists just because of its existence & not because of any special qualities it has. Also covered are different kinds of causation, form & matter, the existence of mathematical objects, & a prime-mover God.

commentaries: The author contrasts the highest idea in Plato's works, noting the idea of the beautiful in 'Symposion' and 'Phaedrus' versus the idea of the good in 'The Republic'.

raw.author: Hegel
contexts: the old dream that Western metaphysics has dreamed from Parmenides to Hegel
The task of the mind is to understand what happened, and this understanding, according to Hegel, is man’s way of reconciling himself with reality; its actual end is to be at peace with the world.
the old dream which Western metaphysics has dreamed from Parmenides to Hegel of a timeless, spaceless, suprasensuous realm as the proper region of thought?
philosophy from Plato to Hegel was “not of this world,” ... or Hegel admitting that, from the point of view of common sense, philosophy is a world stood on its head, a verkehrte Welt.
Their immediate predecessor was Hegel.

When Hegel finally, in a last gigantic effort, had gathered together into one consistent self-developing whole the various strands of traditional philosophy as they had developed from Plato’s original concept

the “reconciliation with reality,” the catharsis, which, according to Aristotle, was the essence of tragedy, and, according to Hegel, was the ultimate purpose of history, came about through the tears of remembrance.

The great impact of the notion of history upon the consciousness of the modern age came relatively late, not before the last third of the eighteenth century, finding with relative quickness its climactic consummation in Hegel’s philosophy.

To think, with Hegel, that truth resides and reveals itself in the time-process itself is characteristic of all modern historical consciousness, however it expresses itself, in specifically Hegelian terms or not.
The central concept of Hegelian metaphysics is history.
whose history Hegel was consequently able to see as one uninterrupted development of the Spirit.
It can be said that Hegel’s transformation of metaphysics into a philosophy of history was preceded by an attempt to get rid of metaphysics for the sake of a philosophy of politics.
It never occurred to either of them [Vico or Hegel] to apply this concept directly by using it as a principle of action.

History—based on the manifest assumption that no matter how haphazard single actions may appear in the present and in their singularity, they inevitably lead to a sequence of events forming a story that can be rendered through intelligible narrative the moment the events are removed into the past—became the great dimension in which men could become "reconciled" with reality (Hegel), the reality of human affairs, i.e., of things which owe their existence exclusively to men.

To the extent that the teller of factual truth is also a storyteller, he brings about that “reconciliation with reality” which Hegel, the philosopher of history par excellence, understood as the ultimate goal of all philosophical thought, and which, indeed, has been the secret motor of all historiography that transcends mere learnedness.
That is now in the Library of Congress, Arendt analyzes concepts of time from Plato to Augustine to Hegel to Kafka
commentaries: The author mentions Hegel as an endpoint in the historical lineage of metaphysical thought about a timeless realm.
The author references Hegel's philosophical view that understanding historical events is a means for man to reconcile with reality and achieve peace.
The author mentions Hegel as an endpoint in the Western metaphysical tradition that dreams of a realm beyond time and space.
The author references Hegel as the endpoint of a philosophical tradition, citing his admission that philosophy appears as an inverted world from the perspective of common sense.
The author identifies Hegel as the immediate predecessor to Kierkegaard, Marx, and Nietzsche, noting his view of world history as a continuous development.
The author references Hegel as the philosopher who synthesized the entire tradition stemming from Plato into a coherent system.
The author cites Hegel's philosophical view that the ultimate purpose of history is a reconciliation with reality, akin to tragic catharsis.
The author identifies Hegel's philosophy as the climactic consummation of the modern historical consciousness.
The author attributes to Hegel the idea that truth resides in the time-process, a characteristic of modern historical consciousness.
The author states that history is the central concept of Hegelian metaphysics.

The author cites Hegel's philosophy of history, specifically his view of world history as a unified, progressive development of Spirit, to illustrate the modern concept of historical process encompassing all mankind.
The author references Hegel's transformation of metaphysics into a philosophy of history, positioning it as a successor to earlier modern attempts to create a philosophy of politics.
The author groups Hegel with Vico, characterizing both as theoretical philosophers of history for whom historical concept was not a direct principle for political action.
The author references Hegel's concept of history as a process that reconciles men with reality through narrative intelligibility.
The author cites Hegel's concept of 'reconciliation with reality' as the aim of philosophy and a driving force in profound historiography.
The author references Hegel as a thinker whose concept of time is analyzed by Arendt in an unpublished document.

raw.title: Critique of Judgment

contexts: Arendt’s great debt to Immanuel Kant’s Critique of Judgment is fully acknowledged for the first time.

I should like to draw upon the first part of Kant’s Critique of Judgment, which, as “Critique of Esthetic Judgment,” contains perhaps the greatest and most original aspect of Kant’s political philosophy.
Critique of Judgment, Paragraph 32.
Ibid., Paragraph 59.
It is this capacity for an “enlarged mentality” that enables men to judge; as such, it was discovered by Kant in the first part of his Critique of Judgment...
Critique of Judgment, § 40.
commentaries: The author states that Arendt acknowledges a significant intellectual debt to Kant's work in developing her ideas on judgment.
The author draws upon Kant's 'Critique of Judgment' to support the use of the term 'taste' and to explore the political philosophy inherent in aesthetic judgment.
The author references a specific paragraph in Kant's 'Critique of Judgment' as a source for philosophical argument.
The author cites another paragraph from the same work, Kant's 'Critique of Judgment,' continuing the reference from the previous citation.
The author attributes the discovery of the 'enlarged mentality' necessary for judgment to Kant's Critique of Judgment, while noting Kant's failure to recognize its political implications.
The author cites a specific section from Kant's 'Critique of Judgment'.

goodreads_match.title: Critique of Judgment
goodreads_match.description: In THE CRITIQUE OF JUDGMENT (1790), Immanuel Kant (1724-1804) seeks to establish the a priori principles underlying the faculty of judgment, just as he did in his previous critiques of pure and practical reason. The first part deals with the subject of our aesthetic sensibility; we respond to certain natural phenomena as beautiful, says Kant, when we recognize in nature a harmonious order that satisfies the mind's own need for order. The second half of the critique concentrates on the apparent teleology in....

raw.author: Nietzsche
contexts: It is as though Marx, not unlike Kierkegaard and Nietzsche, tried desperately to think against the tradition while using its own conceptual tools.
Kierkegaard, Marx, and Nietzsche stand at the end of the tradition
that “school of suspicion” which, according to Nietzsche, constitutes modern philosophy.

It is rather interesting to note that Nietzsche, who once used the term “eternize”—probably because he remembered the passage in Aristotle—applied it to the spheres of art and religion. In Vom Nutzen und Nachteil der Historie für das Leben, he speaks of the “aeternisierenden Mächten der Kunst und Religion.”
This is the reason for Nietzsche’s remark in “Schopenhauer als Erzieher”: “Ich mache mir aus einem Philosophen gerade so viel, als er imstande ist, ein Beispiel zu geben.”
commentaries: The author groups Nietzsche with Marx and Kierkegaard as great 19th-century thinkers who attempted to think against the Western tradition while still being constrained by its conceptual framework.
The author cites Nietzsche as one of the thinkers at the end of the philosophical tradition, who radicalized Hegel's approach by questioning Platonic hierarchies.
The author references Nietzsche's characterization of modern philosophy as a 'school of suspicion', linking it to Descartes' methodological doubt.
The author notes Nietzsche's adaptation of a term from Aristotle, referencing his work 'Vom Nutzen und Nachteil der Historie für das Leben' to show its application in art and religion.
The author references Nietzsche and quotes him (from an essay, not a book) to support a point about the value of a philosopher's personal example. The author is cited as a source of the idea.

goodreads_match.title_without_series: Relativity: The Special and General Theory
goodreads_match.title: Relativity: The Special and General Theory
goodreads_match.description: Relativity is the most important scientific idea of the 20th century. Albert Einstein is the unquestioned founder of modern physics. His Special & General theories of Relativity introduced the idea to the world. In this classic short book he explains clearly, using the minimum amount of mathematical terms, the basic ideas & principles of his theory of Relativity. Unsurpassed by any subsequent books on Relativity, this remains the most popular & useful exposition of Einstein's immense contribution to human k...

goodreads_match.title: Das Kapital
goodreads_match.description: Das Kapital, Karl Marx's seminal work, is the book that above all others formed the twentieth century. From Kapitalsprung the economic and political systems that at one time dominated half the earth and for nearly a century kept the world on the brink of war. Even today, more than one billion Chinese citizens live under a regime that proclaims fealty to Marxist ideology. Yet this important tome has been passed over by many readers frustrated by Marx's difficult style and his preoccupation with nineteenth-ce...

goodreads_match.title: The Discourses
goodreads_match.description:
For centuries, Stoicism was virtually the unofficial religion of the Roman world
The stress on endurance, self-restraint, and power of the will to withstand calamity can often seem coldhearted. It is Epictetus, a lame former slave exiled by Emperor Domitian, who offers by far the most precise and humane version of Stoic ideals. The Discourses, assembled by his pupil Arrian, catch him in action, publicly setting out his views on ethical dilemmas.
Committed to communicating with the broadest possible audience...

raw.author: Epictetus
contexts: Thus the most persuasive arguments for the absolute superiority of inner freedom can still be found in an essay of Epictetus

It is within one’s self, in the “interior dwelling” (interior domus), where Epictetus still believed man to be an absolute master, that the conflict between man and himself broke out and that the will was defeated.
commentaries: The author references an essay by Epictetus as containing key arguments for the concept of inner freedom.
The author mentions Epictetus as a philosopher who believed in man's mastery over his interior self, contrasting this with the Christian discovery of the will's impotence in that same realm.

The author quotes a definition of freedom from Aristotle's 'Politics' to contrast it with Epictetus's later, inward-focused definition.

goodreads_match.title: Politics
goodreads_match.description:
What is the relationship of the individual to the state? What is the ideal state, and how can it bring about the most desirable life for its citizens? What sort of education should it provide? What is the purpose of amassing wealth? These are some of the questions Aristotle attempts to answer in one of the most intellectually stimulating works.
Both heavily influenced by and critical of Plato's Republic and Laws,Politicsrepresents the distillation of a lifetime of thought and observation. "Encyclopaedic kno...
